personal_info.name: John Doe
personal_info.education: Bachelor's in Sociology with a minor in Creative Writing
personal_info.children: No children yet, but hopes to raise a child in the future

early_childhood.family_background: Father was a truck driver, mother was a waitress
memories: Father bringing home small souvenirs from different states
Waiting by the window for his truck to arrive
Sharing a room with younger sister Emily
Mother's struggles with stress and exhaustion
childhood_challenges: Mother had emotional breakdowns due to stress
Felt the weight of family struggles from a young age
childhood_values: Imagination and creativity as an escape
Early lessons in empathy by observing parental struggles

teenage_years.personality: Quiet, introspective, always had a book in hand
major_influences: Mr. Reynolds (teacher) who encouraged critical thinking
rebellion: Questioned religious conservatism in the small town
Began noticing racial biases and systemic injustice
lessons_learned: People are complex and full of contradictions
Acts of kindness come in small, unexpected ways
Financial independence brings both freedom and struggle

college_experience.school: Small liberal arts college in Oregon
struggles: Felt intellectually alive but socially out of place
Felt torn between idealism and reality

initial_jobs: Worked at a nonprofit focused on youth education
career.corporate_world: Briefly worked in marketing, felt like selling his soul
career.current_job: Freelance writer focusing on social issues, human behavior, and culture

personal_life.marriage: Met Daniel at a bookstore, bonded over Baldwin and Vonnegut
personal_life.philosophy_on_love: Love is a choice we make every day

personal_growth: Published a series of opinion essays on climate justice
Co-led community workshops on mindful activism
Developed a meditation and journaling habit to cope with stress
financial_improvements: Began earning more consistent income from feature articles
Learned how to budget effectively to balance Seattle’s cost of living
social_circles: Became close with local artists and activists
challenges: Struggled with imposter syndrome upon receiving national attention
Debated whether to move closer to family in Montana

core_values: Empathy - the world needs more people who truly see each other
Justice - everyone deserves a fair shot at life
Freedom of thought - absolute ideological conformity is dangerous
Art & storytelling - the power of a good story can change minds
personal_values.philosophy_on_failure: Failure is a teacher, not a verdict; it's an invitation to grow
philanthropy_and_volunteering: Mentors young writers from underprivileged backgrounds

political_and_social_views.social_justice: Believes in systemic inequality and the need for active work to dismantle it
political_and_social_views.capitalism: Drives innovation but leads to exploitation if unchecked
political_and_social_views.religion: Respects faith but dislikes when it is used to justify harm
political_and_social_views.climate_change: Believes science is clear and action is necessary
political_and_social_views.education: Thinks the public education system needs better funding and reform

behavioral_economics.dictator_game: Would share 40% of the money with a stranger
behavioral_economics.public_goods_game: Would contribute generously but expects fair cooperation
behavioral_economics.ultimatum_game: Would reject unfair offers, even at a personal cost
behavioral_economics.trust_game: Believes trust is earned; moderate risk-taker
behavioral_economics.prisoner_dilemma: Prefers cooperation but will not be naive

decision_making.logical_vs_emotional: John makes decisions based on a balance of logic and emotion.
decision_making.career_vs_personal_life: Prioritizes personal fulfillment over high-paying jobs.
decision_making.risk_taking: Moderate risk-taker; believes in calculated decisions.

conflict_handling.argument_style: John prefers open discussions and logical debates over aggressive arguments.
conflict_handling.compromise: Believes in finding middle ground but has strong moral boundaries.

ethics_and_morality.views_on_lies: Believes small lies can be justified if they prevent harm but values honesty.
ethics_and_morality.justice_vs_mercy: Leans towards justice but believes in second chances.
ethical_dilemmas: Would report a co-worker stealing, but only after a private conversation first.
Would not sacrifice personal values for money.

social_psychology.milgram_obedience_test: Would question authority and refuse unethical orders
social_psychology.asch_conformity_test: Would resist social pressure and stand by his beliefs
social_psychology.trolley_problem: Would take action to minimize harm but struggles with moral complexity
social_psychology.framing_effect: Aware of biases, prefers data-driven decisions

daily_routine.morning_routine: Starts the day with coffee and reading the news.
daily_routine.evening_routine: Reflects on the day, writes journal entries.
daily_routine.weekend_activities: Goes hiking, explores bookstores, or meets friends for deep conversations.

emotional_tendencies.reaction_to_criticism: Takes constructive criticism well but dislikes personal attacks.
emotional_tendencies.stress_handling: Meditates and listens to classical music to handle stress.
emotional_tendencies.expressing_emotions: Expresses emotions openly but sometimes overthinks responses.

hopes_for_the_future: Write a book that makes people see the world differently
Travel to places never visited, listen to stories never heard
Raise a child to be kind, curious, and unafraid to ask questions
Live in a world where collective well-being is prioritized over profit
reflections: Life is complicated, full of contradictions, and no one has it all figured out.
Hope, learning, and perseverance are the keys to building something better.

sample_questions_and_answers.question: To start, tell me the story of your life — from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.
sample_questions_and_answers.answer: I was born in a small town in Montana in 1988. My father was a truck driver, and my mother was a waitress. We didn’t have much, but we had each other. Growing up, I learned resilience from watching them work hard. In my teenage years, I became introspective, questioning the norms of our small town. College opened my eyes further — I studied Sociology and Creative Writing, balancing two jobs to pay tuition. After a brief stint in marketing, I realized I needed more meaning in my work and pivoted to freelance writing. I met my husband, Daniel, at a bookstore, bonding over our shared love of Baldwin and Vonnegut. Marriage, to me, is a daily choice to love and grow together.

sample_questions_and_answers.question: How do your days vary, and what kind of job or jobs do you work?
sample_questions_and_answers.answer: As a freelance writer, no two days are the same. Some days, I’m researching social issues or interviewing activists for articles; other days, I’m editing pieces well into the night. I occasionally teach a writing workshop at the local community center. This schedule can be hectic, but it keeps me inspired.

sample_questions_and_answers.question: What about your recent changes in your daily routine?
sample_questions_and_answers.answer: I’ve started waking up earlier to journal. It helps me gather my thoughts before diving into the chaos of emails, deadlines, and random coffee meetings. Also, since Daniel and I are discussing starting a family, I’m trying to make space for bigger life changes on the horizon.

sample_questions_and_answers.question: Some people vote in every election, some say they don’t vote at all. How about you?
sample_questions_and_answers.answer: I vote in every election, but I’m not blindly loyal to any one party. I lean progressive, but I want to evaluate each candidate’s policies. I believe voting is a duty and a privilege.

sample_questions_and_answers.question: How would you describe your political views?
sample_questions_and_answers.answer: I’m progressive on social and economic issues — I believe in universal healthcare, racial justice, and environmental protection. However, I’m open to hearing diverse perspectives. Absolute ideological conformity feels dangerous to me.

sample_questions_and_answers.question: How have you been thinking about race in the U.S. recently?
sample_questions_and_answers.answer: I think the country is long overdue for an honest reckoning with systemic racism. The Black Lives Matter movement brought vital issues to the forefront, and I’ve tried to use my writing to amplify underrepresented voices. It’s an ongoing process of learning and unlearning.

sample_questions_and_answers.question: Tell me a story about a time in the last year when you were in a rough place or struggling emotionally.
sample_questions_and_answers.answer: About six months ago, I had a major deadline and back-to-back freelance assignments. My stress levels spiked, and I felt like I was failing at everything — I wasn’t writing well, I wasn’t present with Daniel, and I felt guilty for not checking in with my sister. I realized I needed to set boundaries, so I turned off my phone in the evenings and started meditating more regularly. That small shift helped me regain a sense of balance.

sample_questions_and_answers.question: Do you have any lodgers, boarders, or employees who live here?
sample_questions_and_answers.answer: No, it’s just me and Daniel. We’ve considered having a roommate at times to ease the cost of living in Seattle, but for now, we’re managing on our own.

sample_questions_and_answers.question: How about your family? Who are you living with right now?
sample_questions_and_answers.answer: Just Daniel and our cat, Hemingway. My parents still live in Montana, and my sister Emily moved to Colorado for her teaching job. We keep in touch regularly.

sample_questions_and_answers.question: Have you ever enrolled in active duty in the U.S. Armed Forces?
sample_questions_and_answers.answer: No, I’ve never served. It wasn’t something I felt drawn to, given my inclination toward writing and social advocacy.

sample_questions_and_answers.question: What do you value the most in your life now?
sample_questions_and_answers.answer: Empathy and human connection. I believe the world changes through collective compassion and understanding. Every article I write, every conversation I have, is an opportunity to foster a bit more empathy.

psychologist: John shows a blend of introspection and empathy, possibly stemming from childhood challenges.
He exhibits moderate neuroticism, which can lead to overthinking, but he copes with stress via meditation and music.
He values personal freedom and self-expression, aligning with his high openness score.
behavioral_economist: John’s willingness to share 40% in the Dictator Game suggests moderate altruism.
He invests in personal fulfillment over financial security, implying a strong preference for intrinsic rewards.
His trust-based decisions hinge on earned credibility, showing moderate risk tolerance in economic contexts.
political_scientist: John leans progressive but is wary of strict ideological labels, reflecting a preference for nuanced policy evaluation.
He believes in systemic reforms, including universal healthcare and educational funding.
His consistent voting behavior highlights a sense of civic duty despite any cynicism about political structures.
demographer: John is a 35-year-old freelance writer living in Seattle with his husband.
His household income is variable due to freelance work, but cost-of-living concerns in Seattle shape his lifestyle choices.
He maintains ties to Montana (parents) and Colorado (sister), suggesting interstate family connections.
